awd_titl_txt: Precision Experiments at Jefferson Lab to Study Specific Electromagnetic Properties of Hadrons
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports two high-profile projects:  the high precision determination of the proton charge radius and the measurement of the probability for an eta-meson (one of the light elementary particles that interact through the strong force) to decay into two photons.  The visible Universe consists mostly of protons; therefore understanding the proton's properties is one of the important tasks of contemporary nuclear physics.  Fundamental symmetries and, most importantly, the ways in which these symmetries are broken, define the physical properties of the eta-meson. These properties, although very critical for the formation of the visible matter, are rather small and require high precision state-of-the-art experiments to be able to "look back" at the early stages of the development of our Universe.  Under this award one undergraduate, one graduate student and one postdoctoral fellow will be trained in highly multidisciplinary experimental nuclear physics.  This award will broaden the participation of under-represented groups in STEM, in that the majority of students at the PI's institution are African American.  

For the past many decades consistent results on the proton charge radius have been obtained between electron-proton scattering and traditional hydrogen spectroscopic measurements. However, recent ultra-high precision measurements of this quantity performed with a novel muonic-hydrogen spectroscopic method gave results up to eight-standard deviations smaller than the average value from all previous experiments.  This clear discrepancy triggered what is now known as the "proton radius puzzle".   The goal of the PRad experiment is to determine the proton charge radius to 0.5% precision.  The projected accuracy of the eta --> 2 gamma decay width will significantly impact the eta-meson sector of the Particle Physics Group (PDG) by significantly improving the rest of eta-partial decay widths. As a result, it will critically improve the light quark mass ratio in a direct and mostly model independent way.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this NSF award (PHY-1812421) two research projects had been carried out by our group: (a) data analysis, extraction of final results and publication of the experiment to measure the proton?s charge radius with a novel independent method and with a high precision; (b) optimization and preparation of a previously approved experiment to run in  Hall D at Jefferson Lab and take data for the life time measurement of one of the light elementary particles (the eta-meson) with a high precision.

The proton is one of the simplest quark-gluon permanently bound system in Nature.  It is possibly the most important building block of all the visible Universe.  As such, the accurate knowledge of its properties is one of the important tasks in nuclear and particle physics.  The size of the proton, also known as its charge radius, is an important quantity in physics. The precise knowledge of its value has a wide variety of impacts ranging from nuclear physics to better understand the strong force that holds the atomic nuclei together and atomic physics (hydrogen spectroscopy) through the determination of the Rydberg constant, one of the central and fundamental constants in physics, in particular, and in all natural sciences, in general.  For nearly half a century the charge radius of the proton had been obtained from measurements of the energy levels of the hydrogen atom (atomic physics) or by scattering of free electrons from hydrogen nucleus (nuclear physics).  In both cases an electron probe had been always used.  Interestingly, the first results obtained from muonic hydrogen experiments (in which the atomic electron is replaced by its heavier ?cousin? known as the muon) were found to be 4.5% smaller than those obtained from regular hydrogen atoms and electron-proton scattering experiments.  This experimental situation was called the ?Proton Radius Puzzle?. Under this award the PRad collaboration continued to analyze the data collected from the new experiment performed in 2016 in Jefferson Laboratory. Our preliminary result on the proton radius, released in 2018 in an international workshop, was one of the critical arguments based on what the International Committee on Physical Constants, the CODATA, in December of 2018 released their updated recommendations for the new value on the proton charge radius. As a consequence, the similar amount of change was recommended for the Rydberg constant, one of the central constants in physics.  The final results of this experiment were published in the Nature journal (Nature, 575, 145-150 (2019)) and played a central role in the Particle Data Group?s (PDG) recent change for the proton charge radius.

The second experimental project had been aiming to measure the probability of the eta meson (η) decay into two gamma particles (γγ) that defining the eta-meson?s lifetime. Fundamental symmetries and, most importantly, their spontaneous and explicit breaking effects in Nature are defining the physical properties of the eta-meson. These effects, though very critical for the formation of the visible matter, are rather small and, therefore, require high precision state-of-the-art experiments to be able to ?look back? at the early stages of the development of our Universe. The projected accuracy of the eta-meson lifetime measurement will significantly improv the rest of the eta-partial decay widths, and, therefore, will critically improve the light quark mass ratio in a direct and mostly model independent way. Under this award we optimized and performed two stages of the experiment in Hall D at Jefferson Lab with collection of high quality, high statistics data sets. Our collaboration, led by our group, is currently in the last stages of completion of the data analysis process, finalizing the extracted physical quantities and preparation for publications. The results will be presented in national and international workshops and conferences.
